> Could you clarify what you mean by "not need a runner" and how that 
> influenced the design of TestResult?

it goes something like this:

TestResult result = new TestResult();
TestCase test = new MyTestCase("testXYZ");
test.run(result);
if (result.wasSuccessful()) {
   S.o.p("hurra!");
}

no need for a TestRunner to execute the test.

I don't particularly like the TestResult and would replace it by some listener
architecture.  But you couldn't run a test without TestRunner like in the above
example anymore.

> > if every test share the same resources, you can potentially have some 
> > very tricky problems:

> Instead of creating a fixture in the constructor and reusing it in each 
> test method -- hoping that testA doesn't screw up the fixture in a way 
> that causes testZ to fail -- you just recreate the fixture anew before 
> each test method.

If you recreate a fixture before each test, you're not _sharing_ a fixture.  The
problem appears when the tests truly share a fixture and when they rely on
another test's result for their execution (like in a create-update-delete test
sequence).
